messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:52): hey, we crossed the 1000 subscriber barrier!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:52): sweet
b07211a0c7cb119232799d2119cea90f (06:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: what big of the spec are you working on now?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:58): none at this very instant
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:58): probably going to go through htmlwg bugs and try to get them down
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (06:59): (i'll work on whatever people want me to work on, so if you have something important, let me know)
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (06:59): Nice!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:00): this week has been hell in terms of getting anything done
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:00): what with everyone and their dog talking about html5 because of Google I/O
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:03): I will admit to being mildly disappointed in the (ahem) wave of recent interest in HTML5 but I'm not quite sure why
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:04): disappointed ho?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:04): how, rather
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:04): disappointed?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:04): he said he wasn't sure why :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:04): that's why i asked how instead :-)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:04): (I have been mildly irked by the garbling of the technical message.)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:04): (But I like that the overall response is positive.)
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:05): yes most of it is probably just seeing "HTML5" become the next "Ajax"
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (07:05): HTML5 is huge. (I mean that in a scope way)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:05): HTML5 is huge, and people use it to refer to things that are not, technically, part of HTML5
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:05): one thing that surprised me in the coverage was how in sync Apple and Google especially are with respect to what is most important in Web technology
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (07:05): And it's building up the "eye-candy" factor that will sell it to the public
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:05): if I didn't know better, I would think it was a conspiracy

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:06): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: if you think that message got garbled, just check out the lower-third text on http://cache.gawker.com/assets/images/gizmodo/2009/05/240ccede5360b093dbf298f8946025a5.png
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:06): (I actually laughed out loud)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:06): so maybe it's just me
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:06): hehe
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (07:07): i'm thinking of making a game
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:07): but I feel like back in the 80s and early 90s, technical reporters seemed to have more of a clue
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (07:07): and if i do, i'll probably use javascript and <canvas>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:07): I remember reading PC MAgazine back in the day
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:07): and it was full of technical facts and stuff
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (07:07): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: did you ever see the coverage of the Morris worm?  they didn't have a clue :-D
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:07): nowadays I look at CNet and I cry
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:07): well I think screen grabs of ridiculous Fox News tickers are practically a genre of their own by now...
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:08): I just don't look at CNet
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:08): ArsTechnica is one of the few beacons of relative technical clue, as far as tech news sites, and even they publish total claptrap at times
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:08): I think the technical audience has moved on and they are all reading each other's blogs instead of magazines
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (07:09): demise of ddj and all that
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:09): with blogs it's hard to tell up front who is full of shit
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:09): unless you are an expert in the particular subject are yourself, or know the person by reputation
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (07:09): i'll help you out. my blog -- http://www.squarefree.com/ -- full of shit.
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:09): like Gizmodo is super popular and clearly appeals to tech enthusiasts but it is at best 50% true
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:09): true
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:10): a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9: I've rarely known you to be full of shit
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:10): depending on the nature of the game, JS + <canvas> is probably a decent choice
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:10): have you seen olliej's fluid dynamics demo?
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (07:11): then i left it open in a background tab and wondered why my computer was hot
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:11): I don't know why but I find it endlessly fun to play with
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:11): it does manage to replicate that feature of Flash games
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:12): whoah he managed to boost the frame rate
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:12): where is it?
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (07:12): imagines the new cookie cutter industry: "Free, Addictive HTML5 Games!"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:12): I'm getting nearly 60 fps here
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:12): http://nerget.com/pressure/pressure.html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:12): i just get a black screen :-(
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:12): it numerically approximates the solution to the Navier-Stokes equations of fluid dynamics
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:12): oh i see
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:12): you have to click
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: you have to click or drag to make things happen
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:13): and if you toggle the view, it flips from pressure to velocity
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:13): I wanna put this up on webkit.org but I have to get rid of the layout table first
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:13): or people will laff at us
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:13): ooh, fun
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:14): Dear CSS Layout, Please learn how to be easy like tables. Love, The Internet.
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:14): now it just needs the audio equivalent of <canvas> and you can add splooshy sounds
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:14): realtime audio generation is very hard
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:14): the latency requirements to get smooth realtime sound generation are ridiculous
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:15): so it's a much harder problem than canvas :-/
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (07:15): is mesmerized
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (07:15): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: latency requirements?
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (07:15): what makes it different from graphics?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:16): a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9: for audio to feel reactive, you need a fairly small buffer - audio delay is much more noticeable than video
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:16): a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9: but on the flip side, if you don't fill the buffer in time, you get horrible sounding artifacts
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:17): this is why things like CoreAudio and OpenAL are so complicated
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (07:18): games do fine choosing prerecorded sound effects and timing them to go with the video
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (07:18): that's what js8080 does for space invaders, etc, using <audio>
a131216c7af242e66537a58b4ca7c9f9 (07:19): what changes when you're creating the sound effects on the fly?
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (07:19): I would like a openal type api for audio however (in the browser)
e2633ed61085592add6e058692dfff2f (07:19): you can generate wav data and use data url's to <audio>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:20): with prerecorded sounds, you don't have the problem of the audio output buffer underflowing cause you couldn't fill it fast enough
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:21): having an ImageData like approach where you provided a large-ish buffer that gets mixed in might work
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:21): but doesn't have much of an obvious advantage over using <audio>
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (07:23): switches back to the fluid dynamics window and discovers The Blob
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:28): I wish olliej let you control the viscosity

8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (07:51): way to go twitter
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (07:52): Wow. Twitter doesn't escape ampersands
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (07:52): gotta be an XSS waiting to happen in that somehow, I'd expect
eca88ce0deea1275223afe139b2595e2 (07:53): Mm, not really
